fields.description:
I had a user 'user01' in account 'rusvika', which was assigned a policy to do
anything on ec2. From time to time, euca-describe-instances would show me some
instances (In 'terminated' state) belonging to user 'ken' of account 'ken'.
Interestingly, I could not see all Ken's instances, but some.
fields.summary: a user of non-eucalyptus account is able to see some instances of other accounts

comments.body:
Originally posted on 2012-01-18 01:50:59 by rusvika

Tue Jan 17 17:50:57 2012: Request 5708 was acted upon.
 Transaction: Ticket created by vika.felmetsger
       Queue: Engineering Bugs
     Subject: a user of non-eucalyptus account is able to see some instances of
 other accounts
       Owner: Nobody
  Requestors: Vika.Felmetsger@eucalyptus.com
      Status: new
 Ticket <URL: https://support.eucalyptus.com/Ticket/Display.html?id=5708 >


I had a user 'user01' in account 'rusvika', which was assigned a policy to do
anything on ec2. From time to time, euca-describe-instances would show me some
instances (In 'terminated' state) belonging to user 'ken' of account 'ken'.
Interestingly, I could not see all Ken's instances, but some.

Originally posted on 2012-01-18 06:28:12 by wenye
Ken and I figured out the issue. Vika uploaded an "allow all" policy to the
account. But really the account level policy should only be quotas,
although the code supports it. Since we never tested the account level
policy (non-quota), it has a strange combined effect in describeinstances:
it only shows terminated instances from other accounts (really should show
all instances from other accounts). So  the fix is to add account filtering
in the describeinstances code for terminated cache. It is easy to do. The
remaining decision is whether we should turn off non-quota account-level
policy

Originally posted on 2012-01-18 06:28:40 by wenye
In any case, we should discourage customers to use account level policy
except quotas.

Originally posted on 2012-01-18 07:11:56 by wenye
The VmInstances.list() also has a problem of not filtering on instance id.
So if you do "euca-describe-instances instance_id", it will return any
terminated instances without honoring the specified id.

Originally posted on 2012-01-18 09:33:43 by wenye
Fix committed in ye/eee-merge. Running through QA now.

Originally posted on 2012-01-18 18:38:36 by tjcramer

Wed Jan 18 10:38:36 2012: Request 5708 was acted upon.
 Transaction: Given to wen.ye by tim.cramer
       Queue: Engineering Bugs
     Subject: a user of non-eucalyptus account is able to see some instances of other accounts
       Owner: wen.ye
  Requestors: Vika.Felmetsger@eucalyptus.com
      Status: open

Originally posted on 2012-01-18 19:04:54 by tjcramer
Due to the nature of the circumstances needed to produce this issue (you apply
an "all" policy to non-eucalyptus-admin accounts), and that only terminated
instances are able to be viewed, this will be flagged as a known issue for 3.0

Originally posted on 2012-01-18 19:09:23 by wenye
There are actually more implications. When the system admin runs "euca-
describe-instances", it is supposed to only show instances in "eucalyptus"
account, unless he adds "verbose" to the command. Right now, the code logic
will display all terminated instances even without "verbose". This is not a
serious issue but worth noting.

Originally posted on 2012-01-18 22:59:30 by wenye
Thanks for the clarification, Chris.

This may sound philosophical. But just for the sake of this discussion, I
want to point out that, regardless of the purpose of the parameters of
VmInstances.list(), the end result is that it returns the concatenation of
two lists, one is filtered by account and instance, the other is not. This
is very confusing and comes as a big surprise for anyone who reads the code
or calls the method. And this is exactly what caused the bug. Anyhow, I'm
not insisting on changing that method. Fix at VmControl level is fine too.

The proposed fix does not seem to work. Filtering by permission and
filtering by account are subtly different, specifically for system admin
users. What we need here is to filter the list by account number.

Anyway, let's discuss this after 3.0.

Originally posted on 2012-03-07 02:14:14 by wenye

Tue Mar 06 18:14:14 2012: Request 5708 was acted upon.
 Transaction: Given to grze by wen.ye
       Queue: Engineering Bugs
     Subject: a user of non-eucalyptus account is able to see some instances of other accounts
       Owner: grze
  Requestors: Vika.Felmetsger@eucalyptus.com
      Status: open

Admin user no longer seeing the terminated instances of other users:

{code}
[root@clcfrontend ~]# euca-describe-instances | grep terminated
INSTANCE        i-802F3EF1      emi-78B536F7    euca-192-168-145-173.vic-cloud.euca-qa.com      euca-192-168-145-173.vic-cloud.internal terminated      vic  0
                m1.medium       2013-05-21T05:24:54.697Z        one     eki-DA963794    eri-B0283DC1            monitoring-disabled     192.168.145.173 192.168.145.173                       instance-store
[root@clcfrontend ~]# . admin/eucarc
[root@clcfrontend ~]# euca-describe-instances
RESERVATION     r-29BB3FE1      498025213678    euca-internal-735821391297-tcp-8080
INSTANCE        i-AC113F07      emi-23E636D2    euca-10-0-1-66.vic-cloud.euca-qa.com    euca-192-168-7-140.vic-cloud.internal   running         0            m1.small 2013-05-18T19:43:55.096Z        one     eki-E52E3712    eri-8AAF360B            monitoring-enabled      10.0.1.66       192.168.7.140                instance-store                                                   f503fcdd-732f-40f2-b340-96b8c25ac91f_one_1                              arn:aws:iam::498025213678:instance-profile/internal/loadbalancer/loadbalancer-vm
TAG     instance        i-AC113F07      Name    loadbalancer-resources
TAG     instance        i-AC113F07      aws:autoscaling:groupName       asg-euca-internal-elb-735821391297-tcp-8080
TAG     instance        i-AC113F07      euca:node       10.0.1.94
[root@clcfrontend ~]#
{code}
